# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import seaborn as sns

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode, iplot, plot

import plotly as py
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)

import plotly.graph_objs as go

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.c0af3066:
data['Values']=1
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))

sns.barplot(x=data.groupby('Platform').sum().sort_values('Values',ascending=False).index,
            y=data.groupby('Platform').sum().sort_values('Values',ascending=False).Values
           )
plt.title('Numbers of Platforms Preferred')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()
source.6337d457:
plt.figure(figsize=(12,10))
sns.barplot(x=data.groupby('Genre').sum().sort_values('Global_Sales',ascending=True).index,
            y=data.groupby('Genre').sum().sort_values('Global_Sales',ascending=True).Global_Sales)
plt.title('Most purchased game types ')
plt.show()
source.2f68c748:
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
new_Data=data.groupby('Publisher').sum().sort_values('Values',ascending=False)
new_Data[new_Data.Values>100]
sns.barplot(x=new_Data[new_Data.Values>100].Values,
            y=new_Data[new_Data.Values>100].index)
plt.xticks(rotation=0)
plt.title('Publishers vs Game Numbers (greater than 100) ')
plt.show()
source.ac743259:
plt.subplots(figsize=(17,10))
sns.pointplot(x=data.groupby('Year').sum().index,
              y=(data.groupby('Year').sum().EU_Sales))
sns.pointplot(x=data.groupby('Year').sum().index,
              y=(data.groupby('Year').sum().NA_Sales),color='red')
sns.pointplot(x=data.groupby('Year').sum().index,
              y=(data.groupby('Year').sum().JP_Sales),color='green')

plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.ylabel('Sales')
plt.xlabel('Years')
plt.text(34,330,'Europe',color='blue',fontsize=15)
plt.text(34,315,'North America',color='red',fontsize=15)
plt.text(34,300,'Japan',color='green',fontsize=15)
plt.title('Sales in Regions by Years')
plt.grid()
plt.show()
source.2308ab78:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
sns.pointplot(x=data[data.Platform=='PC'].groupby('Year').sum().sort_values('Year',ascending=True).index,
              y=data[data.Platform=='PC'].groupby('Year').sum().sort_values('Year',ascending=True).Values)
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.title('PC Preference by Years ')
plt.xlabel('Years')
plt.grid()
plt.show()
source.1d82135b:
plt.figure(figsize=(8,8))
sizes=[data.EU_Sales.sum(),data.NA_Sales.sum(),data.JP_Sales.sum(),data.Other_Sales.sum()]
plt.pie(sizes,labels=('North America','Europe','Japan','Other'),explode=(0.1,0.1,0.0,0.0),autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Regions Share in Sales',size=15)
plt.show()
source.0235cb16:
plt.figure(figsize=(8,8))
sns.heatmap(data[['EU_Sales','NA_Sales','JP_Sales','Other_Sales','Global_Sales']].corr(),linewidths=0.5,annot=True)
plt.title('Correlation Map Between Sales',size=15)
plt.show()
source.5ed3583c:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
sns.heatmap(data[['Genre','EU_Sales','NA_Sales','JP_Sales','Other_Sales']].groupby('Genre').sum(),annot=True,fmt = '.1f',linewidth=0.5)
sns.set(font_scale=1)
plt.title('Most Prefered Genre by Region',size=15)
plt.show()
source.b2a993c0:
trace1=go.Scatter3d(x=data.EU_Sales,
                    y=data.JP_Sales,
                    z=data.NA_Sales,
                    mode='markers',
                    marker=dict(size=10))
data2=[trace1]
layout=dict(margin=dict(l=0,r=0,b=0,t=0))
fig=dict(data=data2,layout=layout)
iplot(fig)
source.dd1874e7:
trace1=go.Scatter(x=data.groupby('Year').sum().sort_values('Year',ascending=True).index,
                  y=data.groupby('Year').sum().sort_values('Year',ascending=True).Global_Sales,
                  mode='lines',
                  marker=dict(color='rgba(180,1,1,0.8)'))
data4=[trace1]
layout=dict(title='Global Sales by Years',
            xaxis=dict(title='Global Sales'),
            yaxis=dict(title='Years'))
fig=dict(data=data4,layout=layout)
iplot(fig)
source.ec1318b5:
df1=data[data.Year==2007]
df2=data[data.Year==2008]
df3=data[data.Year==2009]

trace1 =go.Scatter(
                    x = df1.Global_Sales,
                    y = df1.EU_Sales,
                    mode = "markers",
                    name = "2007",
                    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(255, 128, 255, 0.8)'),
                  )

trace2 =go.Scatter(
                    x = df2.Global_Sales,
                    y = df2.EU_Sales,
                    mode = "markers",
                    name = "2008",
                    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(255, 128, 2, 0.8)'),
                    )

trace3 =go.Scatter(
                    x = df3.Global_Sales,
                    y = df3.EU_Sales,
                    mode = "markers",
                    name = "2009",
                    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(0, 255, 200, 0.8)'),
                    )

data = [trace1, trace2, trace3]
layout = dict(title = 'EU sales and Global Sales Chart in the years of highest sales (200,2008,2009)',
              xaxis= dict(title= 'Global Sales',ticklen=7,zeroline= False),
              yaxis= dict(title= 'EU Sales',ticklen= 7,zeroline= False)
             )
fig = dict(data = data, layout = layout)
iplot(fig)
source.41bb495c: ### 4.1-Number of sales of games in regions
source.0f3d8650:
There are 11 columns in dataset and 16598 rows. Information for columns;

-Name: The names of games (object)

-Platform: Platform of the games release (object)

-Year: Dates of games' release (float)

-Genre: Types of games (object)

-Publisher: Game owner (object)

-NA_Sales: Sales in North America (float)

-EU_Sales: Sales in Europe (float)

-JP_Sales: Sales in Japan (float)

-Other_Sales: Sales in others regions (float)

-Global_Sales:Total sales (float)
source.f29f4918: ### 6.2-In which region, which genres were the most sold ? The interest in action games is quite high in the North America region.
source.64d34a4b:
-go.Scatter ---> Type of graph.

-mode ---> type of plot like marker.

-color ---> color of lines. RGB (red, green, blue)

-layout ---> It allows adding features for graphics by using it in dictionary type. Title, length of x axis ticks, zero line etc.
source.74052edf: ### 3.3-Most Purchased Game Types Action games are both the most preferred game type and the most paid game type totally.
source.ec831c6f: ### 3.4-Numbers of games for publishers The platform that produces the most games is Eletronics Arts.
source.dfd82f2d: ## 4-Point Plot -sns.pointplot() ---> Selection of graph type. -x and y ---> Series -xlabel and ylabel ---> Titles of axis -text ---> It provides writing on the graph. Location,type and color can be determined. -grid() ---> Shows the lines in the background. -xticks(rotation=) ---> Takes input as an angle to rotate x axis indexes.
source.0d716ff7: ## 5-Pie Plot -plt.pie ---> Selection of graph type. -explode ---> Distance between slices. -autopct ---> It shows values on the graph and digit number of values can be determined. -labels ---> Titles of slices.
source.90576f1d: ### 6.1-What is the correlation between sales region? Correlations of sales volumes in the regions with each other can be seen in the map chart. As the correlation ratio approaches 1, the positive linear relationship increases. The most positive relationship between EU_Sales and Global can be seen in this chart. The proportion in the pie chart can prove this.

source.90d692fe: ## 1-Introduction Dataset shows sales of video games to respect to years,platform, sales region and names. This kernel shows graphical working on Video Games Sales dataset. Plotly and seaborn libraries were used for visual analysis.
source.963cafdf: ### 8.1-In which year were the most games sold? The most game sales were made in 2008 according to global values.
source.8d454b3d: ### 3.2-Which genres were the most preferred? Between 1980 and 2020, the most preferred game type are action games.
source.4d121547: ## 3-Bar Plot -sns.barplot() ---> Selection of graph type. -x and y ---> Series -figsize() ---> Takes 2 input for dimensions of graph.(x and y) -xticks(rotation=) ---> Takes input as an angle to rotate x axis indexes.
source.183c4701: ### 5.1-The Ratios of Regions in Global Sales It can easily be seen that the region with the highest rate of total sales is the EU, and this rate is approximately 50%.
source.59906c0f: ### 3.1-Which game platforms were most preferred? This bar plot (Platforms) was created to show amount of platforms selection for games. As it can be seen in the graph, DS and PS2 are most selected platform. As most of datas belongs to past years, this visualization can be acceptable.
source.d1e37602:
-corr() ---> Makes correlation between given data.

-linewidths ---> Space between small regions.

-annot ---> Shows coleration variables.
